Sir, four most obedient servant. o NOV ‘w V' Additional Deputy Secretary to th overnment of India*Copy of a Memorandum No •1561/18/54, dated the 23rd July 1936, from the Hon’ble the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, to the Foreign Secretary to the Government of India, Simla* Subject:- King's Regulation No*l of 1918* • • • The question of the legality as affecting British subjects of certain taxes imposed by the Muscat state has recently arisen and an investigation into the matter has brought to light the existence of King’s Regulation No.l of 1918, which though disapproved of by the Government of India in their letter No.656-E.A. dated the 16th November 1918 seems to be still in force owing to lack of evidence that it was ever disallowed and its disallowance published as required by Article 80 (1) of the Muscat order in Council. 2. The object of King’s Regulation No.l of 1918 was simply to ensure the compliance on the part of British subjects with the Arms Traffic Regulations of the Sultan of Muscat. In effect however, it not only made British subjects subject to these regulations but to 'any recognised local law or custom in Muscat” thus going directly against the first sentence of sub para (2) of Article 6 of the 1891 Treaty and Article 13 which gives British subjects the rights of ex-territoriality,since obviously if a British subject was made subject to any law passed by the Sultan ex-territoriality disappears. A further and serious defect in the King's Regulation in question was that in section 2 the Political Resident was not made the authority as in section 2 of King's Regulation No.l of 1935- of deciding what law should be applicable but merely whether an offence had been committed against such law. It seems obvious thatHis Majesty's Government do not regard as being in force the King's Regulation No* 1 of 1918, otherwise there would not have been any necessity for the issue of King's Regulation No. 1 of 1935♦ 3* For the reasons given above and to regularise the position, it is desirable to repeal the King's Regulation No.l of 1918 by publishing its disallowance by Government* The method of such publication in Muscat is merely to post a notice upon the Agency board for so many days so is not likely to cause comment. I propose taking this action, but before doing so, I shall be glad to have a copy of Government of India Foreign and Political Department's reply to Colonel Trevor's letter No.793 of 12th May 1920, enclosing a draft King's Regulation on local laws and customs, the last paragraph of which suggested that the Kind's Regulation of September 1918 should be repealed . titleInfo.title: Coll 25/21 'Orders in Council: Muscat: Muscat King's Regulation no 1 of 1918 - repeal of; Kings Regulation no 1 of 1937'

physicalDescription.extent: The file is arranged in chronological order from the back to the front.

Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 19; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: Correspondence and memoranda relating to the repeal of Muscat 'King's Regulation, No. 1 of 1918'. Copies of 'King's Regulation, No. 1 of 1937', which repealed the original one, are included (folios 9-12).The correspondence is between officials at the Foreign Office, India Office, Political Residency in the Persian Gulf, and the Government of India, Foreign and Political Department.
